sub_topic: Solving homogeneous systems of linear equations
message_2:
To find the solution set for the given homogeneous system of linear equations, we can use the Gaussian elimination method to reduce the augmented matrix to its row echelon form.

The augmented matrix for the given system is:

$$
\left[\begin{array}{ccc|c}
1 & -2 & 3 & 0 \\
2 & 1 & -1 & 0 \\
1 & 1 & -4 & 0
\end{array}\right]
$$

First, we can eliminate the 2 in the second row, first column, and the 1 in the third row, first column. To do this, we can perform the following row operations:

$$
R_2 = R_2 - 2R_1 \\
R_3 = R_3 - R_1
$$

This results in:

$$
\left[\begin{array}{ccc|c}
1 & -2 & 3 & 0 \\
0 & 5 & -7 & 0 \\
0 & 3 & -7 & 0
\end{array}\right]
$$

Next, we can eliminate the 3 in the third row, second column. To do this, we can perform the following row operation:

$$
R_3 = R_3 - \frac{3}{5}R_2
$$

This results in:

$$
\left[\begin{array}{ccc|c}
1 & -2 & 3 & 0 \\
0 & 5 & -7 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 0 & 0
\end{array}\right]
$$

Now, we have reached the row echelon form of the augmented matrix. The corresponding system of linear equations is:

\begin{cases}
x_1 - 2x_2 + 3x_3 = 0 \\
5x_2 - 7x_3 = 0 \\
\end{cases}

We can express $x_2$ in terms of $x_3$:

$$
x_2 = \frac{7}{5}x_3
$$

Now, we can substitute this expression for $x_2$ into the first equation:

$$
x_1 - 2\left(\frac{7}{5}x_3\right) + 3x_3 = 0
$$

Simplifying, we get:

$$
x_1 = \frac{1}{5}x_3
$$

Now, we can express the solution set as a linear combination of the free variable $x_3$:

$$
\begin{bmatrix}
x_1 \\
x_2 \\
x_3
\end{bmatrix}
=
x_3
\begin{bmatrix}
\frac{1}{5} \\
\frac{7}{5} \\
1
\end{bmatrix}
$$

So, the solution set for the given homogeneous system of linear equations is:

$$
\left\{ x_3
\begin{bmatrix}
\frac{1}{5} \\
\frac{7}{5} \\
1
\end{bmatrix}
: x_3 \in \mathbb{R} \right\}
$$
